title: Advice to feed babies peanuts early and often has helped thousands avoid allergies
text:
A decade after a landmark study proved that feeding peanut products to young babies could prevent development of life-threatening allergies, new research finds the change has made a big difference in the real world.

Peanut allergies began to decline in the US after guidance first issued in 2015 upended medical practice by recommending introducing the allergen to infants starting as early as four months.

The rate of peanut allergies in children ages 0 to 3 fell by more than 27 per cent after guidance for high-risk kids was first issued in 2015, and by more than 40 per cent after the recommendations were expanded in 2017.

About 2 per cent of children are affected by peanut allergy. (Getty)

“That’s a remarkable thing, right?” said Dr David Hill, an allergist and researcher at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, and author of a study published on Monday in the medical journal Pediatrics.

Hill and colleagues analysed electronic health records from dozens of pediatric practices to track diagnoses of food allergies in young children before, during and after the guidelines were issued.

“I can actually come to you today and say there are less kids with food allergy today than there would have been if we hadn't implemented this public health effort,” he added.

About 60,000 children have avoided food allergies since 2015, including 40,000 children who otherwise would have developed peanut allergies.

Still, about 8 per cent of children are affected by food allergies, including more than 2 per cent with a peanut allergy.

Peanut allergy is caused when the body’s immune system mistakenly identifies proteins in peanuts as harmful and releases chemicals that trigger allergic symptoms, including hives, respiratory symptoms and, sometimes, life-threatening anaphylaxis.

For decades, doctors had recommended delaying feeding children peanuts and other foods likely to trigger allergies until age 3.

Parents are now urged to introduce peanuts to their kids early. (Getty)

But in 2015, Gideon Lack at King’s College London, published the groundbreaking Learning Early About Peanut Allergy, or LEAP, trial.

Lack and colleagues showed that introducing peanut products in infancy reduced the future risk of developing food allergies by more than 80 per cent.

Later analysis showed that the protection persisted in about 70 per cent of kids into adolescence.

The study immediately sparked new guidelines urging early introduction of peanuts — but putting them into practice has been slow.

Only about 29 per cent of pediatricians and 65 per cent of allergists reported following the expanded guidance issued in 2017, surveys found.

Confusion and uncertainty about the best way to introduce peanuts early in life led to the lag, according to a commentary that accompanied the study.

Early on, medical experts and parents alike questioned whether the practice could be adopted outside of tightly controlled clinical settings.

The data for the analysis came from a subset of participating practice sites and may not represent the entire US pediatric population, noted the commentary, led by Dr Ruchi Gupta, a child allergy expert at Northwestern University.

However, the new research offers “promising evidence that early allergen introduction is not only being adopted but may be making a measurable impact,” the authors concluded.

Advocates for the 33 million people in the US with food allergies welcomed signs that early introduction of peanut products is catching on.

“This research reinforces what we already know and underscores a meaningful opportunity to reduce the incidence and prevalence of peanut allergy nationwide,” said Sung Poblete, chief executive of the nonprofit group Food Allergy Research & Education, or FARE.

The new study emphasises the current guidance, updated in 2021, which calls for introducing peanuts and other major food allergens between four and six months, without prior screening or testing, Hill said.

Parents should consult their paediatricians about any questions.

“It doesn’t have to be a lot of the food, but little tastes of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurts and tree butters,” he said.

“These are really good ways to allow the immune system exposure to these allergenic foods in a safe way.”

Tiffany Leon, 36, a Maryland registered dietician and director at FARE, introduced peanuts and other allergens early to her two young sons.

At first, Leon’s own mother was shocked at the advice to feed babies such foods before the age of 3, she said.

But Leon explained how the science had changed.

“As a dietician, I practice evidence-based recommendations,” she said.

“So when someone told me, ‘This is how it’s done now, these are the new guidelines,’ I just though, OK, well, this is what we’re going to do.”

The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute’s Department of Science Education and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The AP is solely responsible for all content.

title: Aussie researchers discover breakthrough link between breastfeeding and fighting cancer
text:
A﻿ustralian scientists have made a breakthrough discovery in why breastfeeding and pregnancy reduces the long-term risk of breast cancer in women.

It is widely accepted that childbirth and breastfeeding can protect women against the deadly disease – but until now, the biological reason has been linked to hormones.

Researchers at ﻿the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in Victoria, led by Professor Sherene Loi, have found that childbirth develops infection-fighting T-cells in the breasts, which continue to "live" in breast tissue for decades.

A﻿ustralian scientists made a breakthrough discovery in why breastfeeding and pregnancy reduces the long-term risk of breast cancer. (Getty)

Loi and her team discovered ﻿that patients who had these T-cells had a better outcome of fighting cancer and generally had healthier breast tissue.

"These cells act like local guards, ready to attack abnormal cells that might turn into cancer," Loi said.

"This protection may have evolved to defend mothers during the vulnerable post-pregnancy period, but today it also lowers breast cancer risk, especially the aggressive type called triple-negative breast cancer."

The study used data from over 1000 breast cancer patients.

Of those women, the ones who had children were found to have significant﻿ly more T-cells.

And, in some groups, they lived longer after a breast cancer diagnosis.

Researchers at ﻿the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in Victoria made the discovery. (Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre)

Any period of breastfeeding provided benefits, however six months was the most ideal, Loi said.﻿

"When breast cancer cells were introduced, the models with this reproductive history were far better at slowing or stopping tumour growth but only if T cells were present," she added.

It is important to note the research does not claim breastfeeding or childbirth is a guaranteed protection against breast cancer.﻿

Doctors first noticed the link between childbirth and a lower risk of cancer when observing that nuns had some of the highest rates of breast cancer back in the 18th century.

﻿However it was long understood that pregnancy-related hormones were a major factor in preventing cancer.

Around 58 Australians are diagnosed with breast cancer every day.

It is the most common cancer among women and second most-diagnosed cancer in Australia.

title: Radio host helps rescue windsurfer from hazardous Sydney Harbour conditions
text:
Talkback radio host Ben Fordham has rushed to the aid of a windsurfer who found themselves in trouble during a day out on Sydney Harbour.

2GB breakfast host Fordham was about to attend the wedding reception of producer Liam McGuire on Friday afternoon when he heard whistling near Woolwich Dock.

Fordham looked over to the water, noticed a group in trouble and rushed over to help with several other wedding guests.

2GB breakfast host Ben Fordham rushed to the aid of windsurfer who found themselves in trouble during a day out on Sydney Harbour. (2GB)

"They were still in the water﻿ with a windsurf and it was tipped over," he said.

"I yelled out to him 'do you want help?'﻿ and he said 'yes'."

Several people pulled windsurfer Jonah Aiello onto the dock after he went out into choppy waters with friends.

Fordham looked over to the water, noticed a group in trouble and rushed over with his team. (2GB)

"What went wrong was the decision to go out," Aiello told 2GB this morning.

"﻿We knew the forecast, we knew what we were getting into but we thought we'd chase a bit of fun.

"We all just got super overpowered, hadn't been out in a while and everything broke loose.

"Luckily we had a support boat out there as well."

Aiello was uninjured but was left with a few scratches on his nose.

"I had someone say ﻿'I was disappointed', they were hoping I was going to dive right in," Fordham said.

"It was a great se﻿gway to pull you out of the water and start a wedding reception, it really made the afternoon."

After the rescue, the windsurfer was invited into the event but he ﻿politely declined.

"I was in my wetsuit and had all of my windsurfing gear on," Aiello said.

But Aiello extended his own offer to Fordham and his team.﻿

"To any ﻿of the people who helped out, I know you got a bit of saltwater on your suits, so if you want to invoice me for some laundry fees, let me know," Aiello said.

title: How Tony Armstrong's experience of racist trolling inspired series
text:
Warning — this article contains images and references to offensive and racist language.

Gamilaroi man and ABC presenter Tony Armstrong has travelled Australia and abroad to unravel the drivers of racism in sport — and search for positive, practical solutions — in the documentary series End Game.

In it, some of the biggest names in sport leant into the collective ambition of eradicating racism on and off the field.

Former Liverpool football great John Barnes, US Navajo and Angel City FC footballer Madison Hammond, Australian cricketer Usman Khawaja, South Sydney NRL player Cody Walker and dual Brisbane AFL premiership winner Callum Ah Chee all joined the End Game team.

Tony Armstrong shares a laugh with Australian cricketer Usman Khawaja. (Supplied)

Speaking to the ABC as the series premiered, Armstrong was overcome with emotion as he recalled working with former Sydney Swans teammate and childhood hero Adam Goodes.

"It [End Game] wouldn't have worked without him. We didn't want to re-traumatise him, but that's not what happened. He's such a good bloke," Armstrong said, wiping away tears.

Brothers standing united together against racism, Adam Goodes and Tony Armstrong at the SCG. (Supplied)

Goodes is deeply respected by many First Nations peoples across the nation for standing up for himself, his culture, his people and his beliefs.

But despite being a premiership winner and a two-time Brownlow Medallist, in 2013 Goodes was called an "ape" by a teenager during an Indigenous Round match between Sydney and Collingwood.

Goodes 'cut down' because he was powerful: King Charlie King lays down a challenge to AFL to prove it has changed, in the wake of a documentary chronicling the racism that ended Australian footballer Adam Goodes's career.

It was the catalyst for two years of relentless booing on-field and criticism from some media commentators.

"I totally felt like I wasn't getting any respect for the way I was verbalising my situation," Goodes told Armstrong.

" Sometimes you can say and do all the right things, and it still doesn't work. "

After playing for sixteen years at an elite level, the jeers took a huge toll on the former Sydney captain.

Goodes walked away from the sport he loved at the end of 2015.

"For me, once I retired from football, I knew my role was taking a back seat."

Trolling motivated Armstrong to make series

In the decade since Goodes' retirement racist trolling has moved online, with people of all ages suffering the consequences.

A former ABC News Breakfast presenter and two-time Logie award winner, Armstrong said he was motivated to make the series after he faced a high degree of online trolling directed at him, his family and partner.

"I basically got to a point where I'm copping a fair bit. I can handle it at this point in time," he said.

" It's incumbent on me [to make the series] with the position I'm in professionally, how I'm seen in Australia. I felt like I could have an impact. "

Some of the racist trolling aimed at Tony Armstrong and his family. (Supplied)

While in England, Armstrong caught up with Premier League Hall of Fame player Rio Ferdinand who spoke about his personal experiences with racism and the need to apply pressure on the highest levels of the sporting and corporate world to fight it.

"I think the social media companies need to take more of a responsibility to put the little things in place to have consequences for bad practice," he said.

Rio Ferdinand, regarded as one of football's greatest players, opens up about the toll racism took on him and his family. (Supplied)

Legendary West Indian cricketer Michael Holding also shared his motivation for speaking out about racism during a live cricket broadcast at the height of the Black Lives Matter movement in July 2020.

"If you have a platform, use it, and I'm not just talking about black people, white people," he said.

"If you believe that there should be equality use that platform that you have got."

West Indian cricket legend and commentator Michael Holding is calling for athletes to step up. (Supplied)

Australian cricketer and proud Muruwari woman Ash Gardner recalled the attacks she faced for posting on social media her view that it was inappropriate for the Australian cricket team to play on January 26 due to the pain the day brings to First Nations people.

Gardner told Armstrong she found the abuse shocking, but stood by her comments.

"The legacy that I want to leave behind is not actually what I did on the cricket pitch but how I can change things for the greater good," she said.

Tony Armstrong and the End Game crew at the home of Australian cricketer Ash Gardner. (Supplied)

Armstrong said the conversations he had with athletes, particularly from overseas, opened his eyes to the difficulties when calling out racism in Australia.

"One of the things that struck me and made me quite frustrated was overseas they actually say that they've got an issue," he said.

" Whereas here in Australia we're just like, 'nothing to see here, man. What do you mean? We're all happy, aren't we?' "

Armstrong wary of backlash

The series was directed by Guugu Yimithirr man Dean Gibson, who is no stranger to the subject of racism.

In 2021 he directed and wrote the award-winning documentary Incarceration Nation which examined the Australian justice system's treatment of Indigenous people and the historical systemic racism involved.

End Game director Dean Gibson alongside cricketing great Michael Holding. (Supplied: Dean Gibson)

"Sadly, these things happen on a regular basis across the country — over the weekend, across all sporting codes, across all communities across Australia. So we're well aware that this a really prevalent, relevant topic," he said.

The director described Armstrong as "brave and courageous" for the stance he has taken and for being the face of the End Game series.

He acknowledged the risk that Armstrong will again come under significant racist trolling when the documentary airs.

"You could sense that it was weighing on him [Armstrong] as the production grew and he recognised this will be a national conversation, that people will have strong opinions either way," he said.

"He lifted the weight and he really rides that rollercoaster of those emotions. That's real, and I think that's the best part of what he brings to this production."

Tony Armstrong hopes the new series will help to inspire and educate people. (Supplied)

The documentary makers commissioned a survey of 2,111 Australians from social impact agency No 2nd Place about attitudes to sport, fandom and racism.

Only 27 per cent of respondents agreed that racism was an issue in their favourite sport, compared to almost double who agreed that racism was a problem in the country — something the report's authors described as "the ultimate form of rose-coloured glasses".

Know The Real Score Are you game to tackle racism in sport?

Three out of four respondents denied they held prejudice against other cultures.

When an incident of racism had been witnessed, only one out four bystanders agreed they would check on the wellbeing of a victim.

"We shouldn't underestimate how hard it is for a bystander to speak up," Race Discrimination Commissioner Giridharam Sivaraman told the ABC at the official launch of End Game.

" You might feel vulnerable as well. You might be the same colour of skin as the person that's being attacked, and then you're expected to step in and probably you're going to cop it as well. "

Giridharan Sivaraman says eliminating racism on and off the field requires a systemic, national approach. (ABC News: Jack Ailwood)

Mr Sivaraman said the National Anti-Racism Framework launched by the Australian Human Rights Commission last year offered "much bigger solutions … that change our systems and institutions so that the racism that we see on streets, on trains, in schools doesn't happen".

Mr Sivaraman said the neo-Nazi attack on the Camp Sovereignty protest site in August was a sign that racism was on the rise.

"The fact that neo-Nazis openly, without masks or sunglasses and in broad daylight, attacked Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, that's hugely concerning," he said.

Loading...

Can sports drive positive change?

With the first of End Game's three episodes airing on Tuesday night, Tony Armstrong and Dean Gibson said they wanted it to inspire and educate.

"The tone from day one was we wanted it to be an empowering piece of television that really empowers First Nations people, but also … people from all backgrounds, to have this conversation and in a respectful, safe and understanding empathetic manner," Dean said.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong will tackle Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport, with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

"People can overcome racism. I think society can overcome it. It just takes the bravery to be the people to talk about it."

The potential of sport to unify people showed up in the survey's finding that 91 per cent of those who felt like they belonged in their favourite sport also felt a sense of belonging in Australian society.

For the filmmakers, their hope is that sport can function as more than just a game, where inclusion transcends prejudice.

"I don't want them to watch this series and be like, 'oh, here's another 'racism sucks, woe is us [story]'. That's not what it's about. This is about giving a set of tools to people," Armstrong said.

Stream all episodes of End Game free on ABC iview or watch on ABC TV at 8:30pm.

title: Thieves steal Victorian town's sign honouring racing legend Larry Perkins
text:
Since the early 1990s, a sign honouring local racing legend Larry Perkins has welcomed people to the far north-west Victorian town of Cowangie.

Last week, however, it was cut down and stolen.

Larry Perkins won the Bathurst 1000 six times. (ABC News)

The sign was believed to be taken between Wednesday and Friday.

Jack Perkins, son of Larry Perkins and a racing driver himself, condemned the act, labelling it as "disappointing" for the community.

"[The sign] is a really cool thing for the community and obviously in the motor racing world," he said.

"That's the thing that really annoys you; when community go to this effort to put something up, they're proud of their town and proud of that particular sign [and then someone steals it]."

Installing sign a community-led initiative

Larry Perkins, who retired in 2003, won the Bathurst 1000 race six times during his career and raced against some of the world's best in Formula 1.

Mildura councillor Glenn Milne said he was shocked by the theft because everyone in the district would be familiar with the sign.

"Larry Perkins is a legend of Cowangie. He was known as the Cowangie kid," he said.

" This isn't just any street sign. It's an iconic sign and it's a piece of Australia's history really … this is something different and it's a pretty low act. "

Glenn Milne says the theft is "sad". (Supplied: Mildura Rural City Council)

The sign was first installed by the Cowangie Country Women's Association in 1993.

It has been replaced twice since, with older, faded signs auctioned off.

Those sales raised about $18,000, which went towards the town's Kow Plains Homestead and old nursing station.

Cr Milne said the funds were valuable to the community.

"That money goes towards looking after those and maintaining those facilities for the people of our community," he said.

"That’s now taken away an opportunity to raise $6,000 or $8,000."

Son urges thieves to take a look in the mirror

Mr Perkins said damage done to the sign's metal poles meant installing a new one would come at an increased cost to the Cowangie community.

Jack Perkins says the theft occurred just days after this year's Bathurst 1000 race. (Supplied: Jack Perkins)

"We'd have to replace the posts," he said.

"Last time we changed the sign, we only had to change the visual sign. The post and everything was still there ... it becomes a bigger job and again it's community driven."

Mr Perkins urged the thieves to return the sign so it could be reinstalled.

Jack Perkins says it would be expensive to replace the stolen sign. (Supplied: Perkins Engineering)

"It doesn't matter if it's a couple of weeks away. If someone gets a conscience and just drops it back on the side of the highway at night, it's just easy. We would be able to weld it back together and it would live to see another day," Mr Perkins said.

"It's just disappointing in 2025 that there's people stealing signs off the highway, like you've honestly got to have a look in the mirror."

He also asked people to keep an eye out for the sign as it was unlikely the thief would be able to sell it without someone reporting it.

title: Victoria and WA coaches announced ahead of AFL State of Origin match
text:
Chris Scott and Dean Cox have been appointed as the respective State of Origin coaches for next February's standalone exhibition match in Perth.

Two-time premiership coach Scott will take charge of Victoria, while Cox will lead Western Australia.

AFL announces State of Origin return AFL chief executive Andrew Dillon confirms Western Australia will play Victoria in Perth next February in the first State of Origin match since 1999.

The two AFL Origin squads will be announced in the coming months.

Players will be selected based on the junior club from where they were drafted.

It will be the first men's State of Origin match since Victoria played South Australia in 1999.

Victoria and Western Australia have not played each other since 1992.

Scott — who grew up in Melbourne — will bring to the "Big V" his experience of winning two flags as Geelong coach, in 2011 and 2022.

He also guided the Cats to grand final appearances in 2020 and 2025.

Cox, who just finished his first season as Sydney Swans coach, came through the WAFL ranks as a player before making his AFL debut with West Coast in 2001.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong will tackle Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport, with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

He was a member of the Eagles' 2006 premiership-winning squad.

"I'm a proud Western Australian and grew up watching State of Origin footy, so this is a real privilege to lead the team in February against the Vics," Cox said in a statement.

"We have a very strong contingent of WA boys playing at the top level so it's not going to be easy to pick a side, but we feel we will take it right up to Victoria.

"I love the fact the concept is back, and I can't wait for the game."

Both Cox and Scott will select three assistant coaches and a high-performance manager ahead of the February 14 match.

title: From MRI scans to wind turbines, critical minerals are essential for modern life
text:
Australia and the US have inked a deal on rare earths and critical minerals.

The critical minerals deal will see about $US8.5 billion invested into various projects over the next six months.

Prior to the meeting, President Donald Trump told reporters on Air Force One, "I don't want to play the rare earths game with China", referencing export controls on a range of critical minerals China hit the US with in April, and expanded recently.

As Australia's ambassador to the US, Kevin Rudd, put it last month: "Australia more or less equals the periodic table, geology has been kind to us."

But being able to mine the raw materials, and having the capacity to process them into something useful, represent two separate challenges.

Australian companies have mostly solved the latter part by selling to China.

Australia sits on huge reserves of critical minerals, but what do they do? Australia is joining the European Union and the United States in establishing strategic reserves of critical minerals, but what do they actually do, and why are they so important?

Earlier this month China placed strict export controls on holmium, europium, ytterbium, thulium, erbium.

In April it slapped similar controls on samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium.

China's position as the world's factory over the past decades, combined with its successful position as the world's dominant miner and processor of rare earths, nickel, lithium and cobalt among others, has seen these minerals move into a massive amount of mundane household items, from vacuum cleaners to headphones.

But elements on this list are also being used in cutting edge nanotechnology and materials research.

Some have also proven to be essential in the advancement of life-saving cancer treatments, powerful medical diagnostics and imaging tools, as well as more undetectable weapons and sharper military intelligence gathering.

The AI boom

The expansion in artificial intelligence (AI)'s capacity is underpinned by the rollout of data centres and high-powered Graphics Processing Units (GPUs).

For example, one of the steps in manufacturing a semi-conductor is polishing the wafer, and cerium oxide has proven to be an effective material in that process.

Other rare earth elements can also improve the manufacturing process.

"Doping rare earth elements in semiconductor materials can adsorb impurities, thereby effectively improving the purity and integrity of semiconductor materials," according to US-based Stanford Advanced Materials.

As chips have become smaller and more powerful, lanthanum oxide has been identified as a better material than silicon dioxide as a component in transistors.

Rare earth elements have improved the manufacturing and performance of semiconductor chips. (Reuters: Florence Lo, file photo)

Medical diagnostics

One heavy rare earth element, gadolinium, has become crucial for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

It's one of the most magnetic elements on the periodic table, and that's made it a useful part of MRI contrast injections.

Gadolinium is paramagnetic, which means it's attracted by an external magnetic force.

So when you're injected with a gadolinium-based contrast, it allows the MRI scanner to produce higher resolution and more accurate images.

In a 2019 paper, South Korean scientists found that adding a range of rare earth elements to CT scan contrast agents, including ytterbrium and gadolinium, provided much better results when compared with an iodine-based contrast agent.

"Doping" an yttrium aluminium garnet with neodymium created the Nd:YAG laser, commonly used in cosmetic medicine as an ablative laser for the reduction of fine lines and wrinkles, tattoo and hair removal.

Gadolinium has proven to be an effective contrast solution in MRI scans. (ABC News: Alison Branley, file photo)

Renewable energy

The magnetic properties of heavy rare earths like neodymium, dysprosium and praseodymium have made them essential in manufacturing of high-performance permanent magnets.

In direct-drive wind turbines, like the ones at the Mt Millar Wind Farm on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula for example, use of these magnets improves efficiency at low wind speeds.

And since they don't have a gearbox, there are fewer moving parts that require maintenance, which lowers running costs.

"The increased demand for wind turbine components and rise in manufacturing capacity for wind energy will drive higher demand for specific materials, including [rare earth elements] such as neodymium, dysprosium, and praseodymium, as well as critical materials like copper, nickel and zinc," the Global Wind Energy Council said in its 2024 Global Wind Report.

They're also vital components of the electric motors and battery chemistry that power EVs, which is tipped to be a key driver of growth in rare earth element demand over coming years.

Wind turbines at Mt Millar use direct drive generators, which require rare earth magnets. (ABC audience submitted: timo29570)

Defence applications

A decade ago, David S Abraham's book The Elements of Power: Gadgets, Guns, and the Struggle for a Sustainable Future in the Rare Metal Age described the F-35 jet as a "flying periodic table".

"The nuts and bolts that hold the plane together are made from beryllium … gallium helps amplify the radar's signal … tantalum sits in the capacitors needed for laser targeting, controls, and cockpit displays'," Mr Abrahams wrote.

Elements like yttrium, gadolinium, dysprosium and terbium have been incorporated into ceramics, alloys and coatings to improve the stealth of military aircraft, missiles and vehicles.

Europium and yttrium are used in night-vision goggles and rare earths have improved heads up displays.

title: How to uncover a workplace's culture before you take the job
text:
When job hunting, you might be looking at things such as pay, hours and location.

But how much do you think about the workplace culture?

"Organisational culture drives an awful lot of worker satisfaction and performance," explains Paula Brough, director of the Centre for Work, Organisation and Wellbeing at Grifith University.

Professor Brough defines workplace culture as the "invisible way that behaviour in the workplace is governed".

"It's often referred to as 'the way things are done around here'," she says.

When the culture at work is toxic, that can be detrimental, says Carol Kulik from the Centre for Workplace Excellence at the University of South Australia

"That's an extra day-to-day strain you are carrying on top of workload.

"And we know over the long run, there is a body of literature that shows having that extra layer of stress is what leads to heart attacks or high blood pressure," she says as examples of physical and mental health conditions that can result from working in a toxic work environment.

It is possible to get a sense of whether an organisation has healthy culture before you take a job.

But it's about more than having a pool table in the lunch room, our experts warn.

Signs of a toxic workplace culture and how to break the cycle A difficult environment can be "systemic", says an expert, but with a new law in place to support employee wellbeing, everyone can play a part in change. It first starts with knowing the signs.

Defining workplace culture

There is formal and informal culture in workplaces, says Professor Brough.

"The formal culture relates to policies and practices, of which there is normally a whole load of HR policies related to that: how you take leave," she says for example.

"Then there is the informal culture … [which] can be anything from the way you talk to colleagues and your managers, to the style of dress, when you take lunch, if you eat at your desk."

We need to care about workplace culture, Professor Kulik says, because organisations can't have a policy or standard operating procedure for every possible circumstance.

" What culture is supposed to do, is fill in any gaps. "

She says when a company has shared values, it has a strong culture.

Security and predictability

'Bring your pet to work day' might be more of a gimmick than a sign of healthly workplace culture. (Pexels)

A healthy workplace culture should give employees a sense of security and predictability, Professor Kulik says, using the example of US-based department store Nordstrom.

"Every department store will say they value customer service, but Nordstrom took it to an extreme and said the most important thing was the customer experience and good service."

When a customer returns something, say a dress, and it appears to have been worn, Professor Kulik says the workplace culture makes it easy for the employee to know what to do.

"It gives it give them some freedom to say, what is most important is service to customer, so I can go ahead and accept this item [regardless of whether it has been worn]."

Sign up to the ABC Lifestyle newsletter Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

A toxic workplace culture may mean an employee feels unsafe, says Professor Brough.

"Any issues around conflict in workplace — that's one of the strongest predictors of psychological injury.

"Any sort of … racial, sexual, gender prejudice that happens — any of those issues obviously produce a very difficult, unsafe, toxic work environment."

Leaving full-time work for comedy Leaving my day job was the only way to circuit break my life back into balance. Six months later, life is very different.

Spotting a workplace culture

There are several ways you can identify a workplace's culture before working there, including their website, reputation, and asking the right questions.

Public image and consistency

You can tell a lot from an organisation's public image, our experts say.

"See what the company says is their culture," suggests Professor Kulik.

"Look at things like their website, their mission statement, their social media."

She says while naturally a company will only say positive things about itself, look for consistency.

"If every time the organisation talks about itself, it's always describing innovation, always talking about community, that is a really good signal."

She says if a company's mission statement says it values diversity and inclusion, you can also try to fact check.

" [If] you look at photos of management and it's all white men, you can maybe question that. "

Reputation

Professor Kulik says to "listen to the stories" of past and current employees.

She says there are useful online workplace review platforms where current and former employees can anonymously share reviews and insights about their employers.

While you are likely to mainly see negative reviews, Professor Kulik says look for consistency.

If the same issue is raised again and again, that might be a red flag.

Professor Brough says if you don't feel comfortable approaching employees directly, you could ask during your interview if there is anyone else you can talk to.

"Most companies, if they didn't have much to hide, would entertain that idea.

"Ask about the more informal aspects of the culture; what's it like working here? Where do people eat lunch?"

Experience with the organisation

You can get a sense of the culture by how the organisation responds to you as applicant, says Professor Kulik.

"If it takes months and months, and you never hear anything, that tells you something about how they value your time."

If you have any direct experience with the company as a customer, client or consumer, for example, that is also worth reflecting on.

Questions to ask

Professor Brough says you should feel confident to ask about company culture during an interview.

Questions like:

How much support do staff receive from managers and each other?

Is there conflict between teams or departments?

What are the career development opportunities?

How much autonomy do I have over where I work, my hours of work, who I work with?

"Autonomy and flexibility is an important predictor of a healthy workplace," Professor Brough says.

What to watch for

Professor Kulik warns not to get "distracted by rhetoric".

"Look for actions, behaviours.

"Don't be distracted by free snacks or bring your pet to work day."

Add to your watchlist The critically acclaimed Mystery Road: Origin returns as Detective Jay Swan (Mark Coles Smith) and Mary (Tuuli Narkle) uncover dark secrets in a haunted timber town, where the past threatens to tear them apart.

Those "gimmicks" might sound nice, but might not be true reflections of company values, says Professor Brough.

"There might be somewhere that talks about having a healthy workplace because they have a walking track to use at lunchtime.

"You think that sounds lovely, but in reality, people are eating lunch at their desks, or it's too hot to go for a walk because there's no shade."

title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies aged 29
text:
American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky has died at the age of 29, his family has said.

"It is with great sadness that we share the unexpected passing of Daniel Naroditsky," the family said in a statement released by his club, the Charlotte Chess Center, on Monday.

"Daniel was a talented chess player, commentator and educator, and a cherished member of the chess community, admired and respected by fans and players around the world."

No cause of death was given.

Born in California in 1995, Naroditsky was one of the United States' most recognisable chess figures.

A former world youth champion, he became a grandmaster in 2013.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong will tackle Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport, with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

In addition to competing – he finished ninth in the blitz world championship last year – he was a popular commentator, writer and online educator.

Naroditsky streamed regularly on platforms such as Twitch and YouTube.

Players and fans praised his teaching skills and friendly personality as tributes poured in from around the world.

"I'm devastated," American world number two Hikaru Nakamura said.

"This is a massive loss for the world of chess."

Danny Rensch, one of the key figures with prominent chess website Chess.com, described Naroditsky as "more than an amazing, inspirational face of our game — he was a friend and brother".

"The news is devastating for the chess world and all who knew him. It’s impossible to put words to this kind of loss," Rensch said.

Reuters/ABC

title: The hidden story behind this painting of a huge bull
text:
A visitor favourite at the Art Gallery of Ballarat is an 1887 oil painting of a man in a top hat standing next to what can only be described as an absolute unit of a bull.

The rectangular beast — built like a proverbial brick shithouse — elicits a giggle from even the most serious gallery-goer.

But the title, Henry Stone and his Durham Ox, does little to explain why such a painting was made in the first place.

If we look through the pages of art history, we can find several other artworks showcasing enormous livestock.

So what's the deal with this niche genre of painting I'm calling "Big Cow"?

Very big cow, or very small man? You decide. (Supplied: National Museums Scotland, National Museum of Rural Life)

Ballarat's ox

Thomas Flintoff was an English-born painter and photographer who spent time in the US before following the gold rush to Victoria in 1853.

He set up a photography and painting studio in Ballarat where he made portraits of locals, and eventually relocated to Melbourne.

Thomas Flintoff's trade cut advertising his premises on Sturt Street, Ballarat. (Supplied: State Library Victoria)

Near the end of his life, he executed the 1.2-metre-wide oil painting of Henry Stone — a wealthy Melbourne butcher — standing with an enormous red bull.

But this painting was no novelty. In fact, it was a very specific reference to a legendary animal from 100 years earlier.

The history of Big Cow art

Since the dawn of time, humans have painted animals.

Indeed, the "Big Cow" genre can be dated as far back as the Upper Palaeolithic period: the famous Lascaux Cave in France contains more than 30 paintings of bulls, the largest measuring over five metres long.

The Lascaux paintings date to around 17,000 to 22,000 years ago. (Image: wikimedia commons)

The Lascaux artists painted wild animals though, as it wasn't until 10,000 years ago that humans began domesticating cattle in the Middle East.

Humanity's reverence for large cattle had always been linked to the ancient knowledge that big cow equals more food, but with the invention of farming came the realisation that more cow food equals bigger cow.

But it wasn't until the 18th century that a boom in selective breeding and animal science really took off in Europe, bringing about new, specially-bred bovine of truly phenomenal proportions.

The OG Durham Ox

In March, 1796 a calf was born on the Ketton Hall estate in Brafferton, north-east England. He was an early Shorthorn, a type of cattle bred specifically to grow to a gargantuan size.

Units of measurement were sometimes inconsistent (or prone to exaggeration) back then, but it's estimated this steer — who became known as the "Durham Ox" — weighed in at more than 1700kg. That's the same as an SUV.

British livestock was going through a boom at the time. The introduction of turnip crops in the 1730s had provided a source of food for cows over the winter, allowing farmers to keep fattening their herds up for longer before sending them to slaughter.

Loading Instagram content

The Durham Ox was a particularly juicy specimen.

In 1801 he was purchased by a travelling showman-agriculturalist named John Day who toured the creature all over the country, turning a nice profit on ticket sales.

It's hard to believe that in the early 19th century people really lined up and paid their hard-earned pennies to see a big cow (I guess they didn't have social media).

But part of John Day's genius marketing strategy was getting the image of the beast out there in front of the public's eyeballs.

Not only did he sell merchandise at his shows, but artists were invited to make paintings, drawings, and (most importantly) prints of the Durham Ox, which circulated far and wide — as far as the fledgling colonies on the other side of the world.

Ceramics like this were popular merch at the fairs and exhibitions where John Day exhibited the Durham Ox. (Image: Bidsquare)

To viewers in the 1880s, Thomas Flintoff's painting in the Art Gallery of Ballarat was making a very clear reference to the original Durham Ox, telling us that this agricultural icon remained ingrained in people's memories for at least a century.

It's telling, too, that although Thomas Flintoff was also a photographer, he was asked to paint Stone's animal, not photograph it.

On one hand, an oil painting better replicates the style of the images of the original Durham Ox (who lived long before the invention of the camera). On the other hand, the painter is better placed to manipulate and exaggerate reality, while the photographer is more tethered to it.

Replicating the style of English agricultural paintings — decades after the invention of photography had made this type of image redundant — was also a way for colonial Victoria to assert its ties to the old world.

Indeed, the landscape in which Henry Stone and his tractor-sized ox stand barely looks recognisable as Australia.

Joan Ross's hand-painted digital collage on paper, Balla Arat, was commissioned by the Art Gallery of Ballarat in 2024. (Courtesy of the artist and N.Smith Gallery, Sydney)

A Ballarat icon

Since it was acquired by the Art Gallery of Ballarat in 1979, Henry Stone and his Durham Ox has been a favourite of locals and visitors alike.

And just as Thomas Flintoff referenced the original Durham Ox in his 1887 painting, contemporary Australian artists have even incorporated the iconic silhouette of Henry Stone's bull into their works, giving new life to this prodigious beast.

Anna Glynn's Flintoff swallows von Guerard, created in 2020, is a tribute to Henry Stone and his Durham Ox. (Supplied: Anna Glynn)

Joan Ross's 2024 digital collage Bella Arat uses Flintoff's Ox to playfully interrogate the ways the Victorian landscape has been shaped by colonialism, while Anna Glynn's 2020 watercolour, Flintoff swallows von Guerard critiques the canon of Australian landscape painting and reflects the sublimation of nature by two centuries of agriculture.

title: Abandoned hotels may help solve rental crisis ahead of Olympic Games
text:
As the majority of regions in Queensland battle vacancy rates of less than 1 per cent and the 2032 Olympic Games pending, tourism organisations and a regional council are turning their attention to abandoned homes, hotels and commercial buildings.

According to Australian Bureau of Statistics data, 192,393 properties were vacant on Census night in 2021, which equated to 8.7 per cent of the state's total dwellings.

In the central Queensland city of Rockhampton, the seven-storey Plaza Hotel with 66 rooms has been closed on and off for the past decade.

Rockhampton Regional Council's Grant Mathers said it was frustrating that the rooms were going to waste.

Grant Mathers says rooms are going to waste while people are homeless. (ABC Capricornia: Vanessa Jarrett)

"Unfortunately, it doesn't send a good message at all. Everyone is dealing with homelessness, people sleeping in the parks and on the streets," the councillor said.

According to REIQ's 2025 Residential Vacancy Rate Report for the June quarter, 34 regions out of 50 in the state have a rental vacancy rate at or below 1 per cent.

Rockhampton's was 0.7 per cent.

"Most parts of regional Queensland are sitting at well below what we consider to be a healthy range, [which is] one that sits between 2.6 up to 3.5 per cent, whereas most parts of regional Queensland and central Queensland in particular are sub 1 per cent," REIQ chief executive officer Antonia Mercorella said.

Antonia Mercorella says rentals are tight across the whole country. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

"So certainly very tight rental conditions, and I should point out that this issue is not necessarily exclusive to Queensland. We are seeing tight vacancy rates across most parts of the country at the moment."

Ms Mercorella said she understood why the community was asking why hotels could not be converted for permanent rental accommodation, but it was not that simple.

"The hotel may not be licensed for that purpose, and there could also be zoning and other council-related regulations that could prevent that, so that's probably one of the primary concerns," she said.

"The other issue is, of course, that in Queensland, permanent rental properties are governed by residential tenancies legislation, and that does come with a series of very strict legislative obligations that may be challenging to meet if you were trying to use a hotel for permanent rental accommodation.

"I'm not saying it's impossible, but there are certainly some prospective obstacles that one would face."

The council has installed a fence around the Plaza Hotel and boarded up access points to deter squatters. (ABC Capricornia: Vanessa Jarrett)

In Rockhampton, the council has gone down the legal route of action against the owners of the closed Plaza Hotel.

It recently had a Public Health Order enforced in court for the clean-up of the hotel site.

"I get it. I don't think local council should have the ability to be able to walk into private residences and demand for this to be done and that to be done, but there are times when we need to act and we need to take the legal opportunities that are available to us," Mr Mathers said.

More short-term accommodation needed

Tourism operators are also frustrated by a lack of short-term accommodation, something they believe needs to be addressed before the 2032 Olympics.

"When it comes to freehold land, it can be really frustrating for organisations like mine, for the general community, for local and state government in regards to them sitting there bare when we have a desperate need for accommodation," Capricorn Enterprise chief executive officer Mary Carroll said.

Mary Carroll says there is a desperate need for more short-term accommodation. (ABC Capricornia: Katrina Beavan)

The Capricorn Resort on the coast in Yeppoon closed in 2016, and its 331 rooms are now deteriorating.

Independent research from Tourism Events Queensland last year found 1,219 short-term accommodation rooms were needed in the Rockhampton and Capricorn Coast region before 2032.

Most of the accommodation is filled by fly-in fly-out workers on construction projects like the $1.98 billion Rockhampton Ring Road and the $983 million Fitzroy to Gladstone pipeline.

"We are desperate for these new short-term rooms because I'm losing short-term accommodation in unit complexes to long-term bookings, either people living in them and taking them out of the rental pool, or major jobs like the Rockhampton Ring Road taking up a lot of rooms with their workers," Ms Carroll said.

The Fitzroy River in Rockhampton is set to host rowing and canoe sprints for the 2032 Games. (Supplied: Rockhampton Grammar School)

The figure was calculated before Rockhampton was named as the host of the 2032 Olympic rowing and canoe sprint.

"We're waiting for that work to be redone to see what that figure will be, but at the moment we're standing here with high 90 per cent occupancies across our region for much of the year," Ms Carroll said.

With more sports set to be held across regions in the state, Ms Mercorella said it would not be just accommodation needed for the games, but the construction leading up to it.

"We really need to be thinking about how we're going to be creative about ensuring that we have adequate accommodation," she said.

"We'll need to think very carefully about how we're going to ensure that this event is a success, and how we can continue to house our local population as well as some of those visitors who will be more transient in nature."

title: As this fascinating history of art heists shows, timing is everything
text:
The world's largest art museum, the Louvre, has approximately half a million objects in its collection, with about 30,000 on display, and sees on average 8 million visitors per year. That's big on any scale, with a lot of people and objects to keep watch over. And Sundays are particularly busy.

In a cleverly conceived operation, four men wearing fluorescent vests pulled up at the Louvre in a flat-decked truck at 9:30 on Sunday morning. Quickly setting to work, they raised an extendable ladder to the second storey. Climbing it, they cut through a window, entered the Galerie d'Apollon and, brandishing power tools, helped themselves to nine exquisite objects.

What we know about the Louvre jewellery heist Here are the details on the items stolen in the Louvre heist that unfolded in broad daylight in Paris.

The objects taken were France's royal jewels, formerly belonging to the Empress Eugénie, Napoleon III's wife and arts patron.

This is where it gets tricky for the thieves: What can you do with these priceless objects? They can't wear them — too big and glitzy to go unnoticed — and they can't sell them legitimately as images of them are all over the internet.

The best-case scenario, from the thieves' perspective, is to break them down, melt the precious metals and sell the gems separately.

Empress Eugenie's crown, which the perpetrators took and subsequently dropped as they fled the scene on motor scooters, contains eight gold eagles, 1,354 brilliant-cut diamonds, 1,136 rose-cut diamonds and 56 emeralds. In short, this amounts to a sizeable stash of individual gems to try and sell.

Timing is everything

For the Louvre, any heist is a major blow. It calls into question their security, both electronic and human. Five security staff were nearby and acted to protect visitors, and the alarms did ring, but the entire heist was completed within seven minutes.

Timing is crucial with heists.

In 2019, an 18-karat gold toilet titled America (2016), from the artist Maurizio Cattelan, was stolen from Blenheim Palace, England. It was taken in five and a half minutes. It weighed 98 kilograms and was fully functioning. In other words, the two men who took it (and were later caught and served prison sentences for their crimes) worked quickly and efficiently. At the time of the theft, as gold bullion it was estimated to be valued at $6 million.

Maurizio Cattelan's 18-karat gold toilet, titled America, was stolen in 2019. It weighed 98 kilograms. (AP)

Van Gogh's painting The Parsonage Garden at Neunen in Spring (1884) was stolen from the Singer Laren Museum, in the Netherlands, during its 2020 COVID closure. It was recovered in late 2023 after an investigation by Dutch art detective Arthur Brand.

The 2017 theft of two Gottfried Lindauer paintings from Auckland's International Art Centre took just a few minutes to complete. The thieves ram-raided the front window of the auction house where the paintings, valued at $NZ1 million ($882,000), were displayed. The portraits were recovered five years later through an intermediary, with only minor damage.

Recovering the stolen

The National Gallery of Victoria's Picasso painting Weeping Woman (1937) was famously taken by the Australian Cultural Terrorists in 1986 — but only noticed as missing two days later.

Recovered just over two weeks later, the painting was left for the gallery staff to collect in a locker at Spencer Street railway station. The motivation behind the theft was to highlight the lack of financial support given to Victorian artists, but the true identity of the thieves remains a mystery.

Picasso's The Weeping Woman (1937) was stolen from the NGV by the Australian Cultural Terrorists in 1986. (AAP: Joe Castro)

In 1986, 26 paintings of religious subjects were stolen from the gallery at the Benedictine Monastery at New Norcia, Western Australia.

The thieves were poor planners: They hadn't factored in that three men and the stash of paintings couldn't fit into a Ford Falcon. The paintings were cut from their frames, ostensibly butchered. One was completely destroyed. The thieves were caught and charged.

Where to next for the thief?

Recovery of objects from heists is low. It's impossible to put a number on, but some say art recoveries globally are possibly as low as 10 per cent.

Paintings are more difficult to sell on — you can't change their physical appearance to the point of not being recognised.

However, with objects such as the gold toilet or jewels, the precious materials and gems can be repurposed. Time will tell if the Napoleonic jewels will be recovered.

Never say never. The Mona Lisa (1503), undoubtedly the main attraction at the Louvre, was stolen in 1911 and recovered two years later. The thief, Vincenzo Peruggia, was an Italian handyman working at the Louvre and was caught trying to sell it.

The Mona Lisa, at the Louvre, was stolen in 1911 and recovered two years later. (Reuters: Gonzalo Fuentes)

This latest heist at the Louvre highlights the vulnerability of objects in public collections — the irony being they're often gifted to such institutions for safekeeping.

Those who guard objects are usually paid a minimum wage and yet they are tasked with a huge responsibility. When budget cuts are made, it's often security staff that are reduced — such as the Art Gallery of New South Wales's announcement just last week.

The thieves on Sunday knew what they were after and why. We aren't privy to their motivation. We know the stolen jewels are part of France's history and are irreplaceable. Their theft denies visitors of experiencing them individually for their beauty and craftsmanship, as well as collectively within the context of France's history.

But part of me can't help thinking how the French were partial to helping themselves to artworks and precious objects belonging to others. So perhaps this could be a case of déjà vu.

Penelope Jackson is an adjunct research associate at the School of Social Work and Arts at Charles Sturt University. Her book Unseen: Art and Crime in Australia (Monash University Publishing) will be published in December 2025. This piece first appeared on The Conversation.

title: Former NFL running back Doug Martin dies after struggle with police
text:
Former All-Pro NFL running back Doug Martin died on the weekend after a struggle with police officers who were taking him into custody in Oakland in the United States.

Martin, best known for his stellar career with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, became unresponsive after being arrested early Saturday local time, according to a statement released by the Oakland Police Department.

He was transported by paramedics to a hospital where he died, police said.

He was 36.

A cause of death has not been released. An autopsy will be conducted, the Alameda County Coroner's Office said.

Police said in a statement that Martin was involved in a break-in and that a "brief struggle" happened as police were attempting to detain him.

The department did not release any other details.

Martin, originally from Oakland, lived in Stockton, where he played high school football.

His family issued a statement over the weekend asking for privacy as they grieve.

Police and Oakland's mayor said they had reached out to the family.

"We mourn the loss of Doug Martin, an Oaklander, who had a distinguished NFL career and tragically passed away Saturday morning. Our condolences are with his family and loved ones," Mayor Barbara Lee said Monday in a statement.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong will tackle Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport, with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

His death is being investigated by police, the city police commission, the community police review agency and the county district attorney's office.

Martin was the 31st overall pick in the first round of the 2012 NFL draft after a stand-out career at Boise State.

He rushed for 1,454 yards and 11 touchdowns as a rookie and was selected to the Pro Bowl.

He was named first-team All-Pro and made the Pro Bowl again after rushing for 1,402 yards and six touchdowns in 2015.

Martin finished his career with 5,356 yards rushing and 30 touchdowns in six seasons with the Buccaneers and one with the Raiders.

He also had 148 catches for 1,207 yards and two scores.

"We are deeply saddened to learn of the sudden and unexpected passing of Doug Martin," the Buccaneers said in a statement.

"Doug made a lasting impact on our franchise."

Martin was selected one of the top 50 players in franchise history as part of the team's 50th anniversary celebration.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP

title: 'Perfection on four legs': Legendary Cox Plate winner So You Think dies
text:
Two-time WS Cox Plate winner So You Think has died following a short illness.

Stud Coolmore Australia confirmed the 10-time Group 1 winner died while receiving care at Scone Equine Hospital in the New South Wales Hunter region.

Trained by the late Bart Cummings and Aidan O'Brien, So You Think won back-to-back Cox Plates In 2009-10.

Jockey Glen Boss rode him to his first win and Steven Arnold took the reins the following year.

So You Think also triumphed overseas, with the 2012 Prince of Wales's Stakes at Ascot among his most famous victories.

Via a statement on X, Coolmore Australia said So You Think was "already responsible for 12 individual Group 1 winners" as a sire.

"He was an absolute gentleman, an incredibly kind and intelligent horse and this is a sad day for all the staff that have looked after him so well at Coolmore since he retired in 2012," Coolmore Australia's Tom Magnier said.

"We are so lucky to have had him and watch him develop into one of the country's truly elite sires.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong will tackle Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport, with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

"He provided me with so many great memories on racetracks throughout the world as both a racehorse and a stallion."

Cummings – who looked after 12 Melbourne Cup winners – described So You Think as "perfection on four legs" and the "most genuine horse" he had trained.

Born in 2006 and sired by High Chaparral, So You Think finished third in the 2010 Melbourne Cup.

In 2011-12, he won consecutive Tattersalls Gold Cup in Ireland.

So You Think was inducted into the Australian Racing Hall of Fame in 2019.

title: Strawberries hard to come by as weather extremes affect supply
text:
Strawberries have been harder to find on the supermarket shelves as growers across the country face challenges with the weather.

Queensland's main strawberry season usually finishes in September and October, when growers further south take over.

But hot, dry weather in the Sunshine State is ending the peak season early there, while berries in other parts of the country are ripening later.

Matt Gallace, a strawberry grower from the Mornington Peninsula in Victoria, said a cold winter had set his plants back.

"We're still probably two weeks behind where we would normally be at this time of year," he said.

Coles has informed customers that strawberry supply may be limited. (ABC Rural: Jennifer Nichols)

Production down in Queensland

With unreliable strawberry supplies in recent weeks, prices in the shops have edged up.

Strawberries are currently retailing in the major supermarkets for around $4.50 to $5 for a 250g punnet.

That is much lower than the heady prices of $11.99/250g in Canberra in June 2022, but up from $2.50 a punnet more recently.

Queensland Strawberry Growers Association president Adrian Schultz said weather extremes had resulted in a 20-30 per cent drop in yield during the winter/spring season.

Adrian Schultz says hot weather is ending the Queensland season earlier than usual. (ABC Rural: Jennifer Nichols)

The start of the season was plagued by weeks of rain and damaged fruit that had to be thrown away.

Mr Schultz said a "very, very hot and dry" few days in September and hot days in October were ending the season earlier than usual in key growing areas.

"That finished off a lot of farms up here, there just was no fruit left. It got the plants to shut down," he said.

" It could have an effect on prices over the next couple of weeks until production goes back to normal. "

Hydroponic farms in Queensland, which have more control over water and nutrition by growing strawberries on tabletops, have been able to continue growing fruit for longer.

Ripening has been delayed in Victoria because of cold weather. (ABC Rural: Jennifer Nichols)

Slower ripening in the south

Mr Gallace plants his strawberries at Main Ridge in Victoria between April and June, and usually starts picking from October.

But this year the berries are ripening later.

"Strawberries like warm nights and we haven't had many warm nights over the last few months, so we're behind by about two weeks in terms of our season down here," he said.

He is not the only one, with growers in the Yarra Valley and other southern regions also delayed.

"Everyone is behind and it's just been purely because the climate, the cold winter has just set those plants back a little bit," Mr Gallace said.

But he said it would not be long until picking ramped up.

"Probably another week or two away, the price will start to ease in the supermarkets and your local fruit and veg shop," he said.

Hot, dry weather in the north and cold weather in the south have disrupted strawberry supplies. (ABC Rural: Jennifer Nichols)

Supply to 'return to normal' soon

Major supermarkets Woolworths and Coles have placed signs on the shelves alerting shoppers to the shortages.

"Due to weather impacts on crops, we are experiencing some impact on strawberry supply," a Woolworths spokesperson said.

The spokesperson said there would be more strawberries on the shelves soon.

"We are working closely with our suppliers and anticipate these impacts will only be short-term and supply will soon return to normal," the spokesperson said.

title: Parents of boy who died at hospital say $190m deal will avert 'heartbreak'
text:
The parents of a toddler who died at Northern Beaches Hospital and exposed concerns about its public/private model have applauded a proposed $190 million government deal to wrest back control.

The entire hospital will move into public hands, after the state government reached an in-principle agreement with the receivers of cash-strapped private operator Healthscope.

Taxpayers will fork out $190 million to take control of all 494 beds, while clinical and support staff will be offered jobs with NSW Health.

Since its opening in 2018, the hospital has operated under a public/private model, with Healthscope providing care to public patients under a contract with the government.

However, the death of two-year-old Joe Massa last year exposed a series of deficiencies, leading the state government to negotiate taking back control of the hospital.

Toddler Joe Massa died at Northern Beaches Hospital last year. (Supplied)

Premier Chris Minns said his government was reversing one of the "worst decisions" of the previous Coalition government, which he said had "foisted" a private hospital model on the people of the Northern Beaches.

"Our state's acute hospital services, that provide lifesaving care to the people of New South Wales, should not be privatised," he said.

"Thanks to this decision, no hospital in NSW will be."

Mr Minns confirmed this morning the government would pay $190 million to take over the hospital. (ABC News: Ethan Rix)

He also paid tribute Joe Massa's parents, Elouise and Danny, who have campaigned for the hospital to return to public hands.

"Their advocacy will leave a lasting legacy for every patient and every family who relies on our public health system," Mr Minns said.

Ms Massa said her son's case was not isolated and his love had given the couple the "fierce determination" to fight for the change to the operating model of the hospital.

"We don't want anyone else going through what we have gone through — the absolute torment, the heartbreak," Ms Massa told the media, while holding Joe's shoes.

"I believe it's also Joe's love that has guided the government to ensure that public safety is at the forefront of all decision-making at Northern Beaches Hospital and beyond.

" Joe will leave behind footprints that we will never forget in NSW. "

'Complex' change

The Northern Beaches Hospital. (ABC News: Nicolle Chettle)

In September, the government announced NSW Health staff had been embedded within the hospital, to begin its transition to public hands.

However, Health Minister Ryan Park has repeatedly spoken of the difficulties in taking back a "public portion" of the hospital, while leaving another portion for a private provider.

AMA NSW president Kathryn Austin urged the government to explain what the move to making the hospital a "fully public operation with 'private services'" will mean in practice for patients, staff and service providers.

Mr Park said on Tuesday the operating model and partnerships with private providers at the hospital had not yet been settled but he did not foreshadow a reduction in services.

NSW Health Minister Ryan Park with Elouise and Danny Massa. (ABC News: Abbey Haberecht)

Mr Park said navigating the change in hospital structure and management had been "complex" and "challenging" and the deal was an "important step forward".

"It [the deal] marks the beginning, not the end, of what will be a change in model of the way in which that hospital works," he said.

He said he did not have an overall cost to the government for taking over the hospital.

Treasurer Daniel Mookhey said the $190 million deal would just cover the money spent to build Healthscope's facilities, not past or future profit, in a departure from the initial contract.

The in-principle agreement will now go to Healthscope lenders group for approval, Mr Mookhey said.

Many of the hospital's facilities are shared, creating significant challenges when it comes to the division of assets.

While bringing the whole hospital into public control will eliminate that uncertainty, it will raise more questions about the future of the specialist services currently offered at the facility.

NSW Nurses and Midwives' Association general secretary Shaye Candish said it had been an "extremely unsettling and stressful time" for staff at the hospital and welcomed the proposed deal.

title: SA government hopes generator sales can recoup shelved hydrogen plant costs
text:
South Australian taxpayers will fork out more than $250 million on generators for the scrapped Whyalla hydrogen plant — but the state government says it is confident it will recoup the money through a competitive sale process.

A report by the state's auditor-general last week showed the government spent $285.2 million on hydrogen over the past three years, and another $125 million will be paid out this financial year.

The Energy and Mining Department also disclosed an $87.4 million "contingent liability", which the government could be forced to pay for electricity infrastructure around Whyalla.

At a parliamentary committee hearing on Monday, the opposition seized on the figures as evidence "South Australian taxpayers may be up for $500 million and no hydrogen plant to show for it".

Reports show the SA government has spent $285.2 million on the scrapped hydrogen plant at Whyalla. (ABC News: Brant Cumming)

Auditor-general Andrew Blaskett replied: "Certainly that is a correct interpretation if all of the costs come to fruition in terms of the contingent liability, but also if you don't include the recovery of costs through the turbine sale".

The government insists much of the cost will be recouped or can be invested and used elsewhere.

SA government's $285m spend on hydrogen revealed South Australia's Office for Hydrogen Power spent more than $280 million before the state government scrapped the agency amid the failure of its Whyalla hydrogen project.

The Malinauskas government had allocated $593 million to build a hydrogen power plant in Whyalla, setting up an Office for Hydrogen Power in May 2022 to deliver on its pre-election hydrogen promises.

The hydrogen project was effectively cancelled in February 2025 after months of speculation about a cost blowout as the private sector pulled out of green hydrogen projects across Australia.

The government said it diverted the money for the hydrogen project to support its takeover of the embattled Whyalla steelworks.

Auditor asked not to reveal turbine costs

Mr Blaskett said the government intended to recover the cost of the turbines.

But he said the department asked him not to disclose how much the government had paid for them "as it may impair their sale process".

Hours later, Treasurer Tom Koutsantonis revealed the government was spending upwards of $250 million on the turbines.

"Currently today there is a three-year wait on anyone wanting to buy new generators so we are in an excellent position to recoup these costs in full," he said.

Tom Koutsantonis has said the expenditure on early works could be reinvested. (ABC News: Ashlin Blieschke)

"We spent money on land, which we own, we spent money on electrical infrastructure and substations for the steelworks which they will use and ultimately pay for, and we will recoup the cost of the generators in full if not more than they cost us."

The government's $285.2 million spend over three years included $85.7 million which was written off because it related to early works on designing hydrogen production and storage in Whyalla.

Mr Koutsantonis has said the $85.7 million expenditure on early works can be used in the future — but Mr Blaskett said such a scenario was unlikely.

"It's not unheard of but very rare, I think, for something that's been written off in the nature of this to come back and actually have value in the future," Mr Blaskett said.

Mr Blaskett said the extra $125 million, to be paid by the end of this financial year, also included some expenditure on the turbines — but he was unable to give a breakdown.

Regarding the "contingent liability", Mr Blaskett said it is not yet known how much of the $87.4 million the government will need to pay.

"If industrial take-up in the Whyalla area means that electricity companies are able to recover the cost of the infrastructure they've put in by charging to other clients, then there's certainly potential for it to be much lower," he said.

Opposition energy spokesperson Stephen Patterson said the government's spending on hydrogen was "scandalous".

"The government have been tricky in saying they'll use the turbine to recover some of the capital costs," he said.

"But it was quite clear in black and white that of this $500 million there is over hundreds of millions of dollars that is not related to capital costs that can't be recovered."

title: Caitlin grew up playing baseball with the boys. Now she's on the cusp of history
text:
When Caitlin Eynon was 12, she faced a choice between following her peers into softball or pursuing the male-dominated sport she really loved — baseball.

A decade later, it is a decision that has her on the cusp of history, as American baseball prepares for the return of a professional women's league after a 70-year hiatus.

Eynon, 22, who grew up playing baseball predominantly in male teams, was accepted into the draft for the upcoming Women's Pro Baseball League (WPBL) in the United States.

Caitlin Eynon says she hopes to be a role model for girls. (Supplied: Caitlin Eynon)

The Perth local said she continued playing in the hope of one day inspiring others.

"A lot of girls get pushed into softball, so I think trying to be that person … to show them that you can play baseball — you can do what you want to do" she said.

"I've got two older brothers. They both played baseball growing up, so it was sort of a family thing."

Eynon beat over 450 hopefuls to form part of a 150-prospect draft pool for the new league launched by women's baseball pioneer Justine Siegal.

Turning hobby into a career

The shortstop fielder and batter continued playing baseball as a "hobby" and was entirely self-funded.

"The thought of actually being paid to play the thing that you love to do every day is pretty exciting," Eynon said.

"It was cool to see some sort of pathway being put in place for girls … they have something to look up to now. It's like no — you could actually make a professional career out of this."

The opportunity to earn a living from baseball comes despite what Eynon described as "geographical challenges" faced by Australian baseballers.

"We don't get exposed to anywhere near the level of competition than the rest of the world," she said.

Caitlin Eynon fielding for the Australian Emeralds. (Supplied: Caitlin Eynon)

Even applying for the WPBL was not easy with Eynon unable to attend in-person tryouts in the US, instead creating a video package highlighting her skills.

Perth to world stage

Eynon has spent three years at the Braves Baseball Club in Perth, and said it been an "awesome" place to progress her journey.

"They're so supportive of women's baseball … it's a good, good place to be."

At 13, Eynon appeared destined for great things, making her state women's debut, and by 20, she had represented Australia at a World Cup in Canada.

In April, she received the Golden Arm and Golden Glove awards for her pitching and fielding efforts at the Australian National Championships.

But she is not the only Braves baseballer holding out hope of being drafted in early November, with youth prodigy Leah Cornish also in the pool.

'One of the best'

Cornish, 18, is a catcher and a batter who started playing baseball with her brothers after stints in softball and tee ball.

Much like Eynon, Cornish's baseball resume speaks for itself.

At just 13, she was named the best batter in the WA women's league, and at 15, she won the Golden Bat at the National Championships as part of a title-winning WA side.

Cornish was selected for the 2023 World Cup in Canada as a 16-year-old.

Leah Cornish batting for Perth's Braves Baseball Club. (Supplied: Leah Cornish )

She said representing Australia at such a young age was a great opportunity to observe the best.

"I learn a lot from watching people, so it was definitely cool to watch all of them play and train," she said.

Recently, Cornish spent six months in Quebec playing in the Canada East League, the first elite women's league in the country.

"She's probably one of the best hitters in the country," Eynon said of her teammate.

"She's a lot younger than me but I still learn a lot from her as well."

Loading Instagram content

Amanda Mirco, who coaches both women at the Braves, said she is not surprised they made it into the draft pool.

"They are two of the hardest working players I've seen in my time at the club" she said.

"It's exciting … especially to have two Braves players nominated as part of nine Australians.

"We couldn't ask for better leaders, they are fantastic with the younger girls."

The final draft for the Women's Pro Baseball League will be announced next month ahead of the start of the league in 2026.

title: Gowers explains why Hawks rejected ‘ridiculous’ demands that doomed Merrett trade bid
text:
Hawthorn president Andy Gowers has defended the Hawks’ decision to reject Essendon’s demands for Zach Merrett, declaring it would have been ridiculous to have acquiesced to the Bombers.

And club great Jason Dunstall said he never expected a “cordial” deal to be done, considering the bad blood between the two heavyweight clubs over the decades.

Zach Merrett met with Hawthorn, but a deal couldn’t be done. Credit: Getty Images

Merrett was desperate to join the Hawks during last week’s trade period, but the Hawks and Bombers could not agree to a deal.

The Hawks offered two first-round selections, a future first-rounder and fringe midfielder Henry Hustwaite, but the Bombers wanted four first-round selections and a second-rounder.

title: Australia news LIVE: AUKUS reaffirmed, critical minerals deal signed in Albanese-Trump meeting; $11.7 million cocaine shipment seized by AFP, Chilean police
text:
Speaking from the Osborne Naval Shipyard in Adelaide this afternoon – a site where nuclear-powered AUKUS submarines are being manufactured – Minister for Defence Richard Marles has praised the outcome of today’s meeting between Albanese and Trump as an “important affirmation of the AUKUS program”.

“The meeting between our Prime Minister and President Trump was a really important affirmation of the United States’ and Australia’s commitment to the AUKUS program.
